text: This is a list of South Korean regions by GDP. All data are sourced from the latest regional statistics published by the South Korean Government, the OECD and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).World Economic Outlook Database, International Monetary Fund. Implied PPP conversion rate The South Korean won has been converted to the international dollar using the IMF's Purchasing Power Parity conversion rate. == By GDP (PPP,2016) == {| class="wikitable sortable" !Rank !Region !GDP in mil. !Comparable country |- |1 |Gyeonggi |$425,716 | |- |2 |Seoul |$408,265 | |- |3 |Chungnam |$133,917 | |- |4 |Gyeongnam |$123,247 | |- |5 |Gyeongbuk |$112,979 | |- |6 |Busan |$92,838 | |- |7 |Incheon |$92,453 | |- |8 |Ulsan |$81,448 | |- |9 |Jeonnam |$77,987 | |- |10 |Chungbuk |$64,166 | |- |11 |Daegu |$56,793 | |- |12 |Jeonbuk |$53,600 | |- |13 |Gangwon |$47,688 | |- |14 |Daejeon |$41,071 | |- |15 |Gwangju |$38,496 | |- |16 |Jeju |$19,335 | |- |17 |Sejong |$12,764 | |- |– | |$1,934,033 | |} == By GDP per capita (2018) == {| class="wikitable sortable" !
